      • Research internship at RMIT University, Melbourne using mathematics to model problems involved with wildfires. My supervisor was Prof. Dr. John Hearne from School of Science (before School of Mathematical and Geospatial Sciences). We used both Julia and Python to do research on planning of emergency responses to fire as well as prescribed burning to prevent wildfires for growing large. The latter will result in a paper "A spatial optimisation model for fuel management to break connectivity of high-risk regions while maintaining habitat quality" (Manuscript, 2016)Research internship at RMIT University, Melbourne using mathematics to model problems involved with wildfires.   • Winners 7th annual AIMMS-MOPTA Modeling Competition 2015Winners 7th annual AIMMS-MOPTA Modeling Competition 2015
    Issued by AIMMS · Jul 2015Issued by AIMMS · Jul 2015
      Associated with University of TwenteAssociated with University of Twente
      • The challenge revolves around Project Portfolio Management. Companies are likely to develop several new products at the same time, given the risk of delays or failures on each project, and the need to adapt products to an ever changing marketplace. In the present case, both teams have to create a working model in order to assist management with the selection of projects to pursue, over a three-year horizon, subject to risk constraints. The members of this team were Victor Reijnders, Martijn Schoot Uiterkamp, and Mike Visser, advised by Bodo Manthey. Our approach consisted of generating a large set of possible combinations of “bad luck” which could impact project planning. Our optimization model incorporated these combinations, helping planners assess things that could possibly happen. The winner was announced at the MOPTA Conference banquet in Bethlehem, PA. (http://coral.ie.lehigh.edu/~mopta/competition)The challenge revolves around Project Portfolio Management. Companies are likely to develop several new products at the same time, given the risk of delays or failures on each project, and the need to adapt products to an ever changing marketplace. The members of this team were Victor Reijnders, Martijn Schoot Uiterkamp, and Mike Visser, advised by Bodo Manthey. Our approach consisted of generating a large set of possible combinations of “bad luck” which could impact project planning. Our optimization model incorporated these combinations, helping planners assess things that could possibly happen. The winner was announced at the MOPTA Conference banquet in Bethlehem, PA. AboutAbout

PhD researcher both at the Probability and Statistics group at the Mathematical Institute and at the Econophysics and Network Theory group at the Physics Institute of Leiden University. His research focuses on the phenomenon of Breaking of Ensemble Equivalence for Complex Networks.
Experience with programming languages Mathematica, Matlab and Python.PhD researcher both at the Probability and Statistics group at the Mathematical Institute and at the Econophysics and Network Theory group at the Physics Institute of Leiden University. His research focuses on the phenomenon of Breaking of Ensemble Equivalence for Complex Networks. Experience with programming languages Mathematica, Matlab and Python.
